name: Andreas Glans

name: Fifi D'Orsay

name: James Frawley
comments: Actor (stage, film, television) and director (television)

name: Gabriel Dell
comments: Stage and film actor. Dell was a member of the Dead End Kids, a group of young actors from New York who appeared in Sidney Kingsley's Broadway play Dead End in 1935. In 1937 producer Samuel Goldwyn brought all of them to Hollywood and turned the play into a film. They proved to be so popular that they continued to make movies under various monikers, including the Little Tough Guys, the East Side Kids, and the Bowery Boys, until 1958.

name: Edgar Elmes
comments: Stage actor in London musicals in the 1930s and 1940s.

name: Walter Crisham
comments: Character actor, singer and dancer mostly on stage, but also memorable in the 1948 film "No Orchids for Miss Blandish" and as the dancer, Valentin le désossé, in the 1952 movie "Moulin Rouge"

name: Patrick Doyle
comments: Scottish film composer and a long time collaborator of actor-director Kenneth Branagh, He received two Oscar nominations for the Academy Award for Best Original Score for "Sense and Sensibility" in 1995 and for "Hamlet" a year later.

name: Jeremy Northam
comments: English stage, televsion and film actor, who won the Olivier Award in 1990 for "most promising newcomer". He played Ivor Novello in the 2001 film "Gosford Park" and has furthermore appeared in films like  "Emma", "Amistad", "The Winslow Boy" and "Enigma". He played Thomas More in the television series "The Tudors".

name: Christopher Northam
comments: Classically-trained pianist

name: Edward Moore
comments: Lyricist

name: The Striped Bananas
comments: Neo-psych band from Ann Arbor, Michigan. Members: Andrew Lowden, Chantelle Lussier, Duncan Shepard.

name: Rubber Rodeo
comments: New wave pop act  from Rhode Island fronted by Bob Holmes & Trish Milliken.

name: Sybil Crawley

comments: Actor on Westend in London in the 1930s and 1940s.

name: Phil Charig

name: Addy Kleijngeld
comments: Accordionist and leader of the musette orchestra "Le Casse Musette". Later he became producer at the record label CNR and manager of the child star Heintje, which gave him also international renown.

name: Hans Marsa
comments: Composer

name: Elsie Randolph
comments: English actress, singer and dancer. She is best remembered for her partnership with Jack Buchanan in several stage and film musicals. She also appeared in two of Alfred Hitchcock's British films: the 1931 "Rich and Strange" and more than 40 years later in "Frenzy" (1972).

name: Binnie Hale
comments: Actress, singer and dancer. She was one of the most successful musical theatre stars in London in the 1920s and 1930s.

name: Jarl Carlsson
comments: Singer/songwriter, guitarist and pianist.

name: Anica Olsson
comments: Only known for having translated one song.

name: Jack Donahue [US2]
comments: Vaudeville and musical dancer in the 1920s. He starred in the Broadway hits "1920 Follies and between 1925 and 1928 Jack Donahue co-starred with Marilyn  Miller in the hit shows Sunny and "Rosalie". He died in 1930 from the effects of high blood pressure, heart disease and kidney problems.

name: Denis Martin

name: Dudley Savage
comments: Cornish orgainst and broadcaster born in Gulval near Penzance. He was appointed organist at the ABC Theatre in Plymouth in 1938 by Associated British Cinemas.

name: Vernon Midgley

name: Maryetta Midgley
comments: English soprano

name: B.A.S.K.O.

name: Harry Rabinowitz
comments: British conductor and composer of film and television music born in Johannesburg, South Africa

name: Patrice Wymore
comments: American film, television and stage actress of the 1950s and 1960s.

name: The New Symphony Orchestra of London
comments: Orchestra of session musicians for recording under many aliases

name: Aappo I. Piippo
comments: Journalist, translator and lyricist born in Vieremä.

name: Larry Mandon
comments: Name of artist on label of release King's Rhapsody - Part 3 & 4 of whom no further information could be found.

name: Tuula-Helena
comments: Singer born in Keuruu. Mainly active in the 1970s and 1980s, she also recorded under her full name.

name: Hans Jonsson
comments: Bass player and occasional lyricist.

name: Fisher
comments: SInger

name: Davy Burnaby
comments: Actor who made his professional debut at a command performance for King Edward VII. He formed "The Co-Optimists" a London concert party which was very successful. Burnaby was renowned on the London stage and on radio. He made his screen debut in the 1929 film "The Devil's Maze" and appeared in more than thirty films between 1929 and 1948.

name: Willie Redstone
comments: Composer, resident conductor of the Winter Garden Theatre in London and bandleader. One of the two composers of "A Night Out", a 1920 musical comedy which opened at the Winter Garden Theatre, London, on September 18, 1920 with music by Redstone  and music for additional numbers provided by the young Cole Porter as some of his earliest professional work.

name: The Gaiety Theatre Orchestra
comments: The Gaiety Theatre Orchestra is an orchestra often mentioned on releases from the 1920s. The Gaiety Theatre was a West End theatre in London located on Aldwych at the eastern end of the Strand.  In 1868, it became known as the Gaiety Theatre and was -at first - known for music hall and then for musical burlesque, pantomime and operetta performances. From 1868 to the 1890s it had a major influence on the development of modern musical comedy. In 1939 the Gaiety Theatre closed.

name: ScatterTones
comments: Mixed a cappella group from the University of California Los Angeles (UCLA)

name: Jamie Davis
comments: Jazz bariton vocalist born in Ohio.

name: Soldat Louis
comments: Celtic Rock band from Lorient, Brittany

name: Astrid Harzbecker
comments: Schlager singer and songwriter born in Riesa, Sacony.

name: Rob Lindley
comments: Musical acto, who in the 2000s performed in productions of "Oh Coward!" and "Bright Young People: The Songs of Noel Coward".

name: John Sanders
comments: Musical actor who in the 2000s played in "Bright Young People: The Songs of Noel Coward" and the production of "Mathilde", whichopened on Broadway in April 2013 at the Shubert Theatre.

name: Kate Fry
comments: Actress who in 2009 played the lead of Candida in the Writers Theatre (WT) musical adaptation of George Bernard Shaw's "Candida" called "A Minister's Wife" in Chicago. She also played in the 2010 WT production of "Bright Young People: The Songs of Noel Coward". She is the recipient of three Joseph Jefferson Awards, an After Dark Award and Chicago's Sarah Siddons Award.

name: Doug Peck
comments: Pianist, musical director and producer at Writers Theatre in Chicago.

name: Jerry Hahn
comments: Jazz-rock guitarist.

name: Charlie und Co.
comments: Pop trio from Hamburg consisting of Charlie Mille, Wolfgang Borchard-Jacoby and Günter Wessel. The three members had played together before in some combos, e.g. the house band of Tarantella Bar where they had been discovered by Peter Moesser .

name: The Bopcats
comments: Rockabilly band from Toronto

name: Maria Mucke
comments: Singer and actress from Mainz

name: Bert Suplie
comments: Singer

name: Nikki Renée Daniels
comments: Broadway actress and singer originally from Atlanta, Georgia

name: Detlef Engel
comments: Pop singer.

comments: Actor and singer, who has appeared in Broadway musicals and is known for his high tenor voice

name: Cathrine Legardh
comments: Jazz singer and educated music teacher nominated for various awards.

name: Birgitta Sundström
comments: Pop singer.

name: Bo Maniette
comments: Singer-songwriter.

name: Nelson Gonçalves
comments: Singer and songwriter. One of the great Brazilian crooners of his days he gained an international following and appeared at venues such as Radio City Music Hall in New York City. Nelson sold more than 62 million albums around the globe and is the second best-selling Brazilian artist of all time, behind Roberto Carlos

name: Ed Wilson [BR]

comments: Since the mid-sixties, he has been an active part of the mambo and salsa scenes.

comments: Singer-songwriter based in Trondheim. He's also leader of The Autumn Ghost, as well as a part of Kaukasus & Mandala.

comments: Kirsti Huke, Ola Kvernberg & Erik Nylander.

comments: Country & Rock 'n' roll singer from Tennessee.

comments: American jazz bassist.

name: Sonia Leigh
comments: Country music singer-songwriter

name: Los Mac's
comments: One of the pioneers bands of Chilean rock founded in Valparaiso in 1962 and active all through the 1960s.

name: Laban
comments: 1980s duo consisting of Ivan Pedersen and Lecia Jønsson. They originally sang in Danish, before moving onto English language releases. They went on to limited international success.

name: Jason Blynn
comments: Member of Harper Blynn, a New York-based rock band.

name: Pete Harper
comments: Member of Harper Blynn, a New York-based rock band.

name: Risto Klemola
comments: Guitarist and singer.

name: Patrick Fyffe
comments: English female impersonator, best known for playing the character of Dame Hilda Bracket, alongside George Logan as Dr. Evadne Hinge as the duo "Hinge and Bracket".

name: George Logan
comments: Female impersonator born in Rutherglen in Scotland to a musical and theatrical family. He was educated at the Royal Scottish Academy Glasgow and Glasgow University and trained as a classical pianist with a particular interest in opera and vocal music.  In 1970 he met and became friends with Patrick Fyffe and together they formed Hinge and Bracket, making their first appearance in 1972.

name: Sten Nilsson
comments: Singer, saxophone player and co-founder of the band Sten & Stanley , whose other members often back him on solo recordings

name: Hinge and Bracket
comments: Dr. Evadne Hinge and Dame Hilda Bracket were a comedic partnership and the stage personae of a two musical performaners and female impersonation artists George Logan and Patrick Fyffe Active in theatre, radio and television between 1972 and 2002, the year of Fyffe's death, they  entertained the public in the guise of two elderly eccentric spinsters living genteel lives in the village of Stackton Tressel - a fictional, archetypical English village - and seemingly celebrating their former "careers" on the provincial operatic stage.

name: Alan Melville
comments: English broadcaster, writer, actor, raconteur, producer, playwright and wit. He was one of Britain's first television stars. He became chairman of "The Brains Trust" and a panellist in "What's My Line?". He wrote and appeared in many television programmes, among them "A to Z", which ran for two years (1957–58) and played host to more than 400 guests including Bob Hope, Phil Silvers, John Dankworth and Dame Edith Evans.

name: Erik Gullbransson
comments: Operatic and jazz singer, pianist, musical performer, show host and more

name: Charlie Kunz
aliases: Charlie Kunz and His Ballroom Orchestra
comments: American-born British jazz bandleader and pianist, who reached the height of his career in England. He came to England in 1922 as a pianist in a small dance band and became the highest-paid pianist in the world. He was particularly popular during the British dance band era. He made hundreds of records and was top of the bill at music halls throughout the British Isles.

name: The Rescues
comments: Rock quartet from Los Angeles, California

name: Adrianne Gonzalez
comments: Musician, composer, music video director, writer, and painter

name: Chris Kramer
aliases: Crazy Chris Kramer and His Groovehands
comments: Blues harmonicist, singer and songwriter

name: Lizbeth Webb
comments: English soprano and stage actress known as "The Champagne Soprano".  After performing as a dance band vocalist and entertaining British troops during World War II she pursued a career in West End musicals becoming known for her vivaciousness in playing such roles as Linda in Ivor Novello's Gay's the Word and Sarah Brown in the first London production of the Frank Loesser musical "Guys & Dolls" at the London Coliseum in 1953. Webb effectively retired from the stage by the late 1950s to bring up her children.

name: Ryan Cabrera
comments: Singer-songwriter originally from Dallas, Texas

name: Sophie-Louise Dann
comments: Actress on the Londeon Westend stage and in film.

name: Helena Blackman
comments: British musical theatre actress best known for being the runner-up in the BBC1 programme "How Do You Solve a Problem Like Maria?", an English reality television talent show that documented the search for an undiscovered musical theatre performer to play the role of Maria von Trapp in the 2006 Andrew Lloyd Webber and David Ian stage production of "The Sound of Music". Since that time she has appeared in various musical productions.

name: Forrest Kline
comments: Singer- songwriter and guitarist

name: Anita McCloud
comments: Songwriter.

name: Eddie Hustle
comments: Songwriter.

name: Tiffany Taylor
comments: Singer and actress from Baltimore, Maryland.

name: Alana Allen
comments: Actress.

name: DeQuina Moore
comments: Actress

name: Tracee Beazer
comments: Musical theatre actress.

name: Liane Haid
comments: Actress who has often been referred to as "Austria's first movie star". Born in Vienna she trained both as a dancer and singer and became the epitome of the "Süßes Wiener Mädel"("Sweet Viennese Girl") and a popular pin-up throughout the 1920s and 1930s.

name: Johnny Douglas [GB2]
comments: Producer, songwriter and DJ from London

name: John Foreman
comments: Musician, producer and TV personality

name: Casey Donovan
comments: Singer, theatre actress and author, best known for winning the second season of the singing competition show Australian Idol in 2004

name: Tim Campbell [AU]
comments: Television and stage actor, and singer

name: Heather Thatcher
comments: English actress in theatre and films in the first half of the 20th century.

name: Charles Prentice
comments: Born in Prestonpans, Haddingtonshire or East Lothian, Scotland he was a graduate of the University of Edinburgh and - whilst a student there - conducted the Edinburgh University Choral and Orchestral Society. He became the Musical Director for some of the most famous musical plays and shows on the West End stages. He was also an arranger (or what used to be called an orchestrator) and he also taught composition.

name: Tapio Rautavaara
comments: Singer, sportsman and actor who recorded over 300 songs and who was especially popular in the 1940s and 50s. As a sportsman, Rautavaara won a Gold Medal for javelin at the 1948 Olympic Games and was also a champion archer. As an actor he starred in several Finnish films.

name: Guy Louis
comments: Songwriter.

name: Elaine Blighton
comments: British soprano active in the second half of the 20th century and a stage career all over the world.

name: Veronica Lucas
comments: Soprano in classical performances but also in musicals in the 1960s and 1970s.

name: Kostas Bigalis
comments: Singer and musician who is known for representing Greece in the Eurovision Song Contest on two occasions: as a singer and composer in 1994 and as a composer in 1996.

name: Antonis Pappas
comments: Lyricist

name: Achtung Spitfire Schnell Schnell

name: Nancy Lane
comments: Stage and film actress

name: Kay Cole
comments: Stage actress

name: Jackson Hawke
comments: Rock trio. Members: Tim Ryan, Gene Falbo & Bob Yeomans.

name: Kim Hart
comments: Pop singer from Auckland.

name: Janie Marden
comments: Singer and actress

comments: Songwriter

name: Daisy Ridley
comments: Actress, born in Westminster, London.

name: Patrick Wilson [US2]

name: Duke Goff
comments: Country music songwriter

name: Luba Mason
comments: Classically trained stage actress/singer who once starred in the Simon debacle 'The Capeman'

name: Penn Masala
comments: An a cappella group and the world's first South Asian a cappella group. Formed by students at the University of Pennsylvania their music has been influenced by the Eastern and Western cultures that represent the group's membership. The group has released nine full-length albums.

name: Howard McGillin
comments: Actor, originally from Los Angeles, California

name: Michele Pawk
comments: Actress and singer, originally from Butler, Pennsylvania

name: Melissa McCarthy
comments: Movie actress and comedian, originally from Plainfield, Illinois

name: Chris Pine
comments: Movie actor from Los Angeles, California.

name: Waqas Ali Qadri
comments: Rapper and singer-songwriter

name: Lenny Martinez
comments: Lenny Martinez (born in Honduras) is a Danish singer and rapper, who has his roots in Honduras and in Cuba, where he grew up. He is a member of Outlandish and he sings and raps mostly in Spanish in the group's songs.

name: Mintman
comments: Record producer, multi-musician, composer and remixer

name: Jochen Distelmeyer
comments: Singer and songwriter from Bielefeld.

name: Patrick A'Hearn
comments: Singer

comments: Jazz singer.

name: The Atlantic Sounds
comments: Label house band in New York, usually led by King Curtis with the likes of Bernard Purdie on drums and Cornell Dupree on guitar

comments: Stage actress

name: Jon Ballantyne
comments: Pianist and composer

name: Kirsti Huke
comments: Vocalist, composer and band leader crossing over between Jazz and sophisticated pop music. Also appeared as lead singer with a doom metal band.

name: Ronnie Burrage
aliases: Eric Person, Terence Conley, Ronnie Burrage
comments: American jazz drummer. His drumming style draws elements from hard bop, bebop, funk, and soul.

name: Erik Nylander
comments: Jazz drummer, improviser, composer and band leader also participating in many, partly experimental Scandinavian projects. Moved to Norway in 2002.

name: Formo Tre & Metall
comments: One-off project initiated by Jazz Hammond organist Daniel Formo, who also composed all tracks the formation played/recorded except for one.

comments: Experimental Jazz trio.

name: Grace Mitchell
comments: Singer/songwriter.

name: The Weather Station
comments: Singer/songwriter from Ontario

name: Patrick Park
comments: Singer/songwriter.

name: Janet Kilbourn
comments: Songwriter in the late 1960s and early 1970s

name: Pat Johnson
comments: Singer/songwriter.

name: Mary Kay James
comments: American country music artist from Atlanta, Georgia.

name: Marty Mitchell
comments: Guitarist and singer.

name: Racoon
comments: Pop-rock quartet

name: The Mynabirds
comments: Alias of Laura Burhenn. She is joined live by Johnny Kotchian, Dan McCarthy, Pearl Lovejoy Boyd, Ben Brodin and Alex McManus.

name: The Lost [US]
comments: 1960s pop-rock band from Boston.  While active, it released three singles.

name: Ted Myers
comments: Folk and rock guitarist, vocalist and songwriter.

name: Vera Pearce
comments: Stage and film actress whose lengthy career was carried out in both her home country and in England. She moved to the UK in 1922 with one of her earliest shows being "Love's Awakening". She went on to work consistently on the London stage in musicals and pantomimes up until her death. She also appeared in at least 16 films between 1931 and 1966.

name: Garry Marsh
comments: Stage and film actor, who began acting on the stage at the age of fifteen. He started off in films in 1922 as a leading man but later became a character actor. He played in more than sixty films up to 1969.

name: Jordan Young
comments: Jazz drummer.

name: Carlos Perón
comments: Electronics, Dark Wave, themes and soundtracks for fetish movies musician/composer/producer. Though relocating to Cologne, Germany in the early 1990s, Peron is active on an international scale.

name: Stella Mayhew
comments: Headlining vaudeville and musical comedy performer whose career spanned 50 years.  Just before the turn of the 20th century she began to be in demand on Broadway singing "coon songs" usually in black face, From 1902 through 1922 she performed in a team with a singer-dancer named Billee Taylor. She was one of the female blackface singers still active in the 1920s and enjoyed a Broadway hit in 1927 singing "Hallelujah" in a featured blackface rol in the 1927 stage production of Hit the Deck

name: Fran Frey
comments: Singer and saxophonist, best known for his work for George Olsen and His Music in the 1920s and early 1930s. Frey sang on a total of 77 songs with the George Olsen band both as recordings and on the radio. One song entitled Who reached #1 in the US in February 26 and sold more than a million recordings.

name: Ralph Erwin
comments: Austrian-born French composer of film scores. Born in Bielitz, Silesia -  then part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire - he served in the Austrian Army during the First World War. After the war Erwin established himself as a leading German songwriter enjoying a particular hit with Ich küsse ihre Hand, Madame which featured in the 1929 film of the same title. It became the signature tune of Richard Tauber. Bing Crosby later sang an English version in "The Emperor Waltz" (1948). Due to his Jewish origins Erwin went into exile in France following the Nazi rise to power in 1933. He continued to work on film scores. He was later arrested during the Nazi Occupation of France. He died in the Beaune-la-Rolande internment camp after he was shot in the abdomen.

name: Victoria Mallory
comments: Stage actress and singer

name: Jennifer Simard
comments: Broadway actress

name: Clarence Herbert Woolston
comments: Woolston was pastor of the East Baptist Church in Philadelphia and he also wrote lyrics for religious songs.

name: Gary Beach
comments: Stage, TV and film actor

name: Joe Hill
comments: Born in Sweden, Hägglund migrated to the United States in 1902 with his brother. He worked as an itinerant laborer, moving frequently. In 1910, Hill joined the Industrial Workers of the World. and rapidly became a prominent Wobbly, giving speeches and organizing for the IWW, as well as writing political songs and satires under the name Joe Hill.  He had previously used the alias Joe Hillstrom, apparently due to anti-union blacklisting. Hill was convicted of murder in 1915, which he evidently didn't commit. Executed by a firing squad in Utah, he became a martyr and revered figure in the labor movement.

name: Keith Klingensmith
comments: Musician from Detroit, founder of Futureman Records

name: Sopor Aeternus
aliases: Sopor Aeternus & The Ensemble of Shadows
comments: 'Dark Ambient' project from Dieburg (pronounced deebourg...) headed by vocalist/guitarist/keyboarder Anna-Varney Cantodea.

name: This Bike Is a Pipe Bomb
comments: Folk-punk band from Pensacola, Florida active from 1997 to 2011.

name: George Mann
comments: Former union organizer, Mann is still an activist as well as a singer and songwriter.  Mann performs labor and other songs honoring social activism, as well as writing songs himself.

name: Julius Margolin
comments: Labor activist and union organizer from the 1930s, in 1999, he began singing and writing political songs.  He is the subject of the film "A Union Man: The Life and Work of Julius Margolin".

name: Rikki Price
comments: Singer, active in the 1950s and 1960s, who participated in the national preselection to choose the song that would go to the Eurovision Song Contest 1962. He did not win.

name: Billy Goldenberg
comments: Film, stage and television composer, from Brooklyn, New York

name: Anna Bartlett Warner
comments: Novelist and poet; Warner's poems were sometimes set to music to create hymns and religious songs for children.

name: D.A. Foster
comments: R&B and blues singer.

name: Västerås Sinfonietta
comments: Västmanland county's symphonic ensemble.

name: Ben Paterson
comments: Jazz pianist, organist and composer

name: Émile Prud'homme
comments: Accordionist and bandleader. He accompanied Edith Piaf, but also Maurice Chevalier, Luis Mariano, Préjean, Line Renaud and Yves Montand

name: Enjambre
comments: From Fresnillo, Zacatecas. Also featuring Julián Navejas (Keyboards, guiar), Rafael Navejas (Bass), Angel Sanchez (Drums) and Javier Mejia (Guitar).

name: El Tri
comments: Rock band

name: Asdru Sierra

name: Corny Ostermann

He recorded numerous work for labels like Kristall and Imperial. He fought in the German army in World War II and was lost in battle, He was officially declared dead in 1949.

name: Ernst Zebe

After World War II he recorded a numerous amount of recordings on Amiga a record label established in 1947 in the DDR (East Germany). Various Amiga productions have been recorded with a studio band. Such bands were often picked from a selection of the best musicians in the former GDR.

name: The Morriston Orpheus Choir
comments: The Orpheus came into being before the Second World War, following a meeting in Morriston's parish hall on April 9, 1935. At the Forward Movement Hall in Morriston the new Orpheus Choir gave its first public concert on Saturday, July 13. Not even the advent of war in 1939 could lessen the enthusiasms and loyalties of the steel and tinplate workers making up the major part of the Choir. Early in 1948 the Orpheus combined with the Morriston United Choir. The Orpheus began a long series of appearances on the B.B.C.’s “Welsh Rarebit” programmes and it was during this series that the members of the choir and the programme’s resident comedian, Harry Secombe, forged a strong bond of friendship. As a result of these broadcasts the Orpheus made its first records for Columbia. Yet despite the popularity of the broadcasts and the records, when the Orpheus entered the Pwllheli Eisteddfod in 1955 the choir was the only competitor in this field. Welsh choral singing was disappearing.

name: Paul O'Montis

Since he was Jewish like his contemporaries Ralph Erwin, Willy Rosen and Fritz Löhner-Beda he left Germany in 1933 to flee to Vienna and after the "Anschluss" of Austria in 1938 to Prague. He was arrested after the Germans had invaded Prague in 1940 and taken to Sachsenhausen, the concentration camp, where he hanged himself.

name: Dajos Béla
aliases: Dajos Bela et son orchestre viennois
Le maestro Dajos Bela et son orchestre viennois
comments: Bandleader and conductor. Cyrillic spelling: Лев Гольцман (Lev Gol'tzman). Born in Kiev of a Ukrainian father and Hungarian mother, he after serving in World War I, studied music in Moscow and continued studying in Berlin. There he also played at local venues with his own salon orchestra and changed his artist name to Dajos Béla (Dajos was his mother's maiden name), as Hungarian and Romanian music was 'hip' in Germany. His orchestra became one of the most popular in Germany and also gained a high reputation abroad. Upon the Nazis coming to power in Germany in 1933, Golzmann, being Jewish, toured outside the country. Arriving at Buenos Aires in 1935, he remained there for the rest of his life.

name: Skeeter Spight
comments: Jazz singer and lyricist from Detroit, who with Leroy Mitchell , met Sheila Jordan when the latter moved to Detroit as a teenager.  The trio formed a jazz singing group in 1948, Skeeter, Mitch, and Jean (from Jordan's middle name), and Jordan credits Spight and Mitchell with teaching her how to scat.  The group foreshadowed Lambert, Hendricks and Ross . Although the group never recorded, it did sit-in with various national jazz artists when they came through Detroit, including Charlie Parker .  Jordan moved to New York City in about 1950, fed up with the racism in Detroit.  No information was uncovered about Spight or Mitchell after Jordan left for New York.

name: Leroy Mitchell
comments: Jazz singer and lyricist from Detroit.  See, Skeeter Spight for more information about Mitchell and his and Spight's association with Sheila Jordan .

name: Agnes Bernelle
comments: German-born actress and singer based in the UK, later in Ireland.

name: Veigar Margeirsson
comments: Film score composer

name: The Lounge-O-Leers
comments: Kitschy pop duo

name: Craig Stuart Garfinkle
comments: Composer, whose career includes work on feature films, video games, trailers, documentaries, multimedia, network television, commercials, stage musicals and albums.

name: Simone Benyacar
comments: Simone Benyacar is a composer at Ant Farm, an entertainment advertising agency in Hollywood. Simone has been responsible for music supervision and original compositions for a wide variety of campaigns for movies but also for video games.

name: Daniel Nielsen
comments: Composer of film scores and pianist. He started his career during his teenage years and has numerous scores to his credit. Not only is he associated with motion picture music, film music and advertising campaigns’ musical themes, but also with Sky Sports’ theme.

name: Helen Terry
comments: Singer perhaps best known for her backing vocal work with Culture Club

name: Mutt Evans
comments: Country singer and guitarist who performed with the Dixon Brothers. Mutt Evans is best known as the mayor of Durham, North Carolina from 1951 to 1963.

name: Judy Lunn
comments: Singer.

name: Travis Scott
comments: Hip hop recording artist and record producer from Houston, Texas

name: Jim Yester
comments: Pop-rock singer, guitarist and songwriter.

name: Giselle Sommerville
comments: Songwriter. Member of Xenomania writing team. Used to be part of the pop duo, Mania

name: Today's People
comments: Pop/soft rock band.

name: The North Door Singers
comments: Group of college students from Graceland College in Lamoni, Iowa. They appeared as finalists on the All American television program.

name: Jean-François Jenny-Clark
comments: French jazz double bass player.

name: Albert Frank Beddoe
comments: Songwriter referred as an influence by a. o. Bob Dylan (who covered Beddoe's most famous song "Copper Kettle" on "Self Portrait").

name: Clem Burke
comments: Rock drummer and composer

name: Pascal Cabero
comments: Musician, songwriter, writer

name: Rémi Sanchez
comments: Singer, songwriter, musician, sound engineer

name: Joël Saurin
comments: Songwriter, musician

name: Vincent Sauvage
comments: drummer, songwriter, writer

name: Jacob Desvarieux
comments: Singer, musician and record producer

name: DJ Fred
comments: DJ, composer, producer

name: Gaëtan Carnasciali
comments: Songwriter, producer

name: Robert Walker [US1]
comments: Blues musician born near Clarksdale, Mississippi

name: Erika Footman
comments: Vocalist and keyboard player. She is the wife of Mark Richardson, drummer, of Skunk Anansie and Little Angels and formerly of Feeder. She toured with Senser in 2013.

name: Friedel Hensch
comments: Singer.

name: Nico Rebscher
comments: Berlin based songwriter and producer. He plays piano, guitar and saxophone. The latter he studied in the Netherlands at the conservatory of Maastricht.  He toured Europe as songwriter for the Goethe Institute and played in various formations. His own band "Lauter Leben" was founded in 2008.

name: Leos Carax
comments: Film director, critic and writer

name: Dick Adamson
comments: Saxophone, clarinet and trumpet player. Bandleader in the 1920s and 1930s. The SS Malolo (later known as Matsonia, Atlantic and Queen Fredrica) was an American Cruise liner built by William Cramp & Sons, Philadelphia in 1926 for the Matson Line. The ship sailed around the Pacific in 1929 on what was called the “Millionaires” Cruise.  The ship called at ports in Asia and the South Pacific.

name: Brighton Rock
comments: Rock band formed in Niagara Falls

name: James Roberts [US]
comments: Early country music singer and mandolin player from Kentucky. When he was just 10 years old he recorded with Asa Martin and his father, Doc Roberts.

name: Gen Tamura
comments: Steel guitar and steel drum player. Tamura has collaborated with rock, pop and experimental music artists, such as Yann Tomita , Kirinji , and Sandii .

name: Sandii
comments: Born in Japan to an American father and a Japanese mother, Sandii moved to Hawaii in the early 1960's to study Hawaiian music and dance, then moved back to Japan in the mid-1970's to launch her artistic career.

name: Hajime Mizoguchi
comments: Cellist, composer, arranger, producer.

name: Lica
comments: Singer.

name: Georgeana Bonow
comments: Bossa nova vocalist

name: Gavin Jasper
comments: Lead singer of rock band, Saints of Valory.

name: Lua Blanco
comments: Actress, singer, songwriter, television director, presenter and occasional model

name: Patty Ascher
comments: Jazz and bossa nova singer.

name: Luiza Fernandes
comments: Bossa nova singer.

name: Martin Hannett
comments: Record producer and co-founder of the Factory label, also known as Martin Zero.  He is credited with creating "the Manchester sound" associated with various punk, new wave and indie acts of the 1970s and 80s.

name: Steve Hopkins
comments: Musician who worked as a session keyboard player, composer, producer, teacher and recording engineer, particularly as part of the Manchester punk scene, until a career switch in the 1990s to atomic physics research.

name: Eliza Lacerda
comments: Bossa nova singer

name: Johnny Warman
comments: Singer-songwriter, best known for his early '80s synth-pop.

name: The Uptown Band
comments: Popular performing blues band in Lansing, Michigan.

name: Julie Moffitt
comments: Singer

name: Georges Guétary
comments: Singer, dancer, cabaret performer and film actor born in Egypt

name: Nancy Harms
comments: Jazz vocalist, born and raised in Clara City, Minnesota.

name: Jason Miles
comments: Keyboardist and songwriter

name: Jerry Byrd
aliases: Jerry Byrd and His Steel Guitar
Jerry Byrd and The String Dusters
Jerry Byrd with the String Dusters
comments: Lap steel guitar player

name: Milo Twins
comments: Country boogie. Identical twins from Copperhill, Tennessee.

name: The Demotrons
comments: Studio group from New York, NY, originally formed to provide the backup music for vocal group recordings.

name: Scott Dunbar
comments: Self-taught blues guitarist and singer who lived his entire life in Mississippi.

name: Robie Porter
comments: Lap steel guitar player, singer, producer, and label owner

name: Vdelli
comments: Blues rock from Perth fronted by Michael Vdelli. They also perform as The Heavy Hitters.

name: Kui Lee
comments: Hawaiian singer-songwriter and entertainer. Of Scottish, Hawaiian and Chinese ancestry, Lee was born in Shanghai and moved to Hawaii with his father when he was five years old. Lee released only one album during his lifetime and wrote no more than 40 songs (many of them were popularized by his friend Don Ho), but is considered a key figure in Hawaiian pop music history.

name: The Miss Alans
comments: Indie rock band from Fresno, initially heavily influenced by R.E.M. .

name: Jack de Mello
aliases: Jack de Mello featuring Hawaii's All Star Orchestra
Orchestra and Chorus directed by Jack de Mello
comments: Musician, producer, and entrepreneur. He recorded more than 150 albums in all types of music, and was also contracted by Hanna-Barbera to compose and orchestrate music for their animated series.

name: Shannon Curfman
comments: Blues rock guitarist, singer and songwriter born in Fargo, North Dakota and now living in Minneapolis, Minnesota.

name: John Randolph Marr
comments: Obscure singer/songwriter.

name: Helen Lindsey Parker
comments: Hawaiian singer and songwriter, known as the “Lark of Waimea.”

name: Louisa Jane White
comments: Pop singer.

name: Sol K. Bright
comments: Hawaiian songwriter, producer, director, actor and entertainer
